column1: Ribeirão Preto (Portuguese pronunciation: [ʁibejˈɾɐ̃w ˈpɾetu]) is a municipality and a metropolitan area located in the northeastern region of São Paulo state
Ribeirão Preto is the eighth-largest municipality in the State with 650.9 km2. It has an estimated population of 674
column2: 534 in 2018 and a metropolitan area of 1
column4: 910. It is located 313 km (194 mi) from the city of São Paulo and 706 km (439 mi) from Brasília
column5: the federal capital. Its mean altitude is 526.8 meters (1
column6: 728 feet) high. The city's average temperature throughout the year is 23 °C (73F)
column7: and the original predominant vegetation is the Atlantic forest.

column1: The city possesses two soccer stadiums

One example is in Franklin Foer's book "How Soccer Explains the World". But it was in the Paulista championships on November 21
column5: 1964 in the coastal city of Santos and against the Ribeirão Preto team that Pelé achieved the incredible feat and his Santos team won by an 11 × 0 score. The 8 goals were payback for the defeat Santos suffered on September 6
column6: 1964 when they visited Ribeirão Preto during the first round of the tournament and lost 2 x 0. Not only had a "small" team beaten one of the "big" teams
column7: but had done so while insulting the "King". A better claim to fame for Botafogo (often referred to as Botafogo-SP) is that Brazilian soccer captains (and brothers) Sócrates and Raí started their careers with Botafogo.

column1: After the New York Stock Exchange crash of 1929 the economy of Ribeirão Preto
column2: based on a single export crop
column3: collapsed
column4: and the city had to adapt to a new situation. Since the city is relatively far from other major Brazilian urban centers
column5: it found a new economic vocation in the services and commercial sector
column6: which was developed to attend the local and regional demands.The second economic boom in the history of Ribeirão Preto occurred after the oil crisis (1973 and 1979) of the 1970s. The increase in the oil price obliged Brazil to look for alternative means of fueling and the solution found was the alcohol fuel program
column7: or Pro-Álcool as it is called. Pró-Álcool led to the development of a technology which allows the use of ethanol (sugarcane alcohol) either as automotive fuel or as a gasoline additive. The latter improves performance and substitutes lead thus decreasing polluting emissions. Due to the Pró-Álcool program
column8: farmers from the region of Ribeirão Preto were encouraged by government subsidies to grow sugarcane. The high productivity of the land around Ribeirão Preto rapidly placed the region as the largest alcohol and sugar producer of the world
column9: being responsible for 30 percent of Brazil's sugarcane alcohol fuel.

column3: Ribeirão Preto's major products are: animal feed
column4: meat

column7: dental materials
column15: beer. The city hosts "Agrishow" on an annual basis
column16: this show being one of the most important agricultural trade shows in Brazil.The sugarcane boom brought a new age of prosperity for the city
column17: which was called the "Brazilian California" during the 1980s and early 1990s. On the one hand
column18: this has increased the city's wealth and turned it into a sophisticated center of services for Brazil and South America but
column20: the image of a new "Eldorado" attracted many migrants from impoverished areas of Brazil leading to a rapid population growth and the appearance of slums (favelas as they are called in Brazil) including all the negative aspects associated with them like drug trafficking and high violence and crime rates
column21: an unfortunate fact that Ribeirão Preto shares with all other major Brazilian cities.The airline Passaredo Transportes Aéreos has its headquarters in the Jardim Aeroporto area of the city.

column1: During the economic stagnation from the 1940s to the 1950s the city discovered and established its vocation as an educational and university center. In 1942 the state government expropriated the Monte Alegre Farm
column2: an important coffee farm from the Schmidt family of German immigrants
column3: and transformed it into an agricultural practical school. Several new buildings and houses for the professors were constructed on a land which held before tens of thousands of coffee plants. The new school was very well planned and urbanized and many trees were planted to provide shadow and give it a pleasant atmosphere. But the agricultural school never achieved a significant development and it was closed in 1951. A longstanding dream of the population of Ribeirão Preto was to have a university and in 1952 the old farm was donated to the University of São Paulo for the creation of a medical school
column4: which was the first school of its campus at Ribeirão Preto.

column2: many original buildings of the agricultural school and even some of the Monte Alegre Farm were preserved and only adapted to hold the new university
column3: which makes its campus one of the most beautiful university campuses in Brazil. After the creation of the medical school the University of São Paulo at Ribeirão Preto (USP-RP) has been growing steadily and it is presently constituted by eight schools: School of Medicine of Ribeirão Preto (FMRP)
column4: School of Law of Ribeirão Preto (FDRP)
column5: School of Philosophy
column7: School of Dentistry (FORP)
column11: School of Nursing (EERP) and School of Music (DMRP-ECA).
